results.title: Shred of evidence
results.brief_description: This program looks at the work done by the Forensic Science Laboratory in London which was founded in 1935. It’s aim is to outwit the criminal and provide evidence for the court. Some scenes may be upsetting to some people.

results.title: Showbiz goes to war
results.creator_credit: Gail Gibson Sedawie, Norman Sedawie, Glen-Warren Productions and T A D Productions
results.brief_description: Hosted by David Steinberg, this documentary about Hollywood stars, World War II and the Hollywood film industry, focuses on the three “P’s” - Patriotism, Propaganda, Pin-ups. Films have always proven to be the great escape during times of hardship, and no more so than during World War II. Hollywood and its stars were the number one morale builder for both the troops and the civilians. Nationalism and patriotism were spawned by the image of the all-American war hero on the big screen prepared to die for his country, a symbol of self-sacrifice whilst at the same time portraying the enemy as a cruel and heartless villain to be destroyed no matter the cost. For the troops it was the entertainment provided by the Hollywood stars that kept them going, in particular, the pin-up girls such as Betty Grable, Rita Hayworth, Jane Russell. And of course there was nothing better than a bit of comedy to lighten up their lives through such stars as Bob Hope and Abbott and Costello. “Showbiz goes to war” is a wonderful documentary put together with many classical film excerpts, trailers, archival newsreel footage of World War II, and includes such Hollywood stars as Fred Astaire, Lucille Ball, Humphrey Bogart, Marlene Dietrich, Clark Gable, James Cagney, Judy Garland, Frank Sinatra, Bing Crosby, John Wayne and a cast of thousands. Watch out for that gem of a comedy sketch by Abbott and Costello “Who’s on first?” - it’s a classic.

results.title: Show me what you look like
results.creator_credit: Brian Nicholson, Michael Whitehead and IKON (GB)
results.brief_description: This is an experimental video. Sound and image do not necessarily correspond. The video moves from realist observation of everyday life to bizarre and surreal flights of fancy. “Show Me What You Look Like” is part of an alternative film and video culture which disregards mainstream concerns with narrative, commerce and exposition, and instead is committed to the production of cultural material which is personal, challenging and down-right weird. The electronic music score is by the English band Durutti Column.

results.title: Show girls
results.creator_credit: Meilan Lam, Barrie Angus McLean, David Verrall, Tamara Lynch and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: ‘Show Girls’ celebrates Montreal’s swinging Black jazz scene from the 1920’s to the 1960’s, when the city was wide open. Three women who danced in the legendary Black clubs of the day - Rockhead’s Paradise, The Terminal, Cafe St. Michel - share their unforgettable memories of life at the center of one of the world’s hottest jazz spots. From the Roaring Twenties, through the Second World War, and on into the golden era of clubs in the fifties and sixties, ‘Show Girls’ chronicles the lives of Bernice, Tina and Olga, mixing their memories with rarely seen footage of the era. Their stories are told against a backdrop of the fascinating social and political history that made Montreal a jazz and nightclub hotspot for decades. It is a story of song and dance, music and pride. (Award: Yorkton.) Narrated by Anthony Sherwood.

results.title: Short vision
results.creator_credit: Joan Foldes, Peter Foldes and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: An experimental film: using a simple animation technique “A SHORT VISION” creates an imaginative and disturbing picture of atomic warfare. A “thing” suddenly appears in the sky, flying over countryside and cities and destroying all living things. All that finally remains is a single flame with a moth fluttering around it; and, after a moment, the flame devours the moth. Music by Matyas Seiber.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joan Foldes, Peter Foldes and British Film Institute

results.title: Short story
results.brief_description: Encourages discussion about how writers choose and select material and use language, using Irish writer Frank O’Connor’s short story “Masculine protest”, about a twelve-year-old runaway, as a basis for discussion.

results.title: Short orders
results.creator_credit: Hal Roach, Percy Pembroke and Hal Roach Studios
results.brief_description: Stan Laurel stars in this silent film as a harried waiter who must deal with customers who have issues with the quality of the food and service in the restaurant. Various comic situations arise. Cast: Stan Laurel, Marie Mosquini, Eddie Baker, Jack Ackroyd, Mark Jones, George Rowe

results.title: A Sporting life
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras looks at popular sports and physical activities in China. Basketball is rising in popularity and China used its excellence in Ping Pong for diplomacy when it was re-opening its doors to the world. Physical education in schools is seen as very important, while Mao Tse-tung encouraged participation in the martial arts as a way of developing a physically, morally and spiritually sound country. The program also examines the different writing styles and the emphasis on balance and movement in forming characters.

results.title: Dragons tongue. - Series 2.
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University
results.brief_description: A series of lessons in the Chinese language intended for high school students using simple vocabulary and brief dramatisations utilising the vocabulary. Includes short sections about life in modern China and a segment on Chinese writing and calligraphy. Introduced by Colin McKerras.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia), Asian Studies Council and Griffith University

results.title: Eating out
results.creator_credit: Robin James, ABC-TV (Australia) and Griffith University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
The eating habits of the Chinese are illustrated through filmed and dramatised segments. We see different kinds of restaurants, factory canteens, and a Chinese family at home during mealtimes. The “History of Chinese” segment describes the different dialects and languages that exist in China emphasising that there is really only one written script for all of these. Vocabulary introduced covers day to day language concerned with mealtimes and shopping for food.
